subject: Polls Close Tuesday
event:
Just wanted to let everyone know that we will be closing the miniatures balloting on Tuesday.  That will be one full week, enough time for everyone to vote.

Barring a flood of new votes in the last few days, it looks as though the winners will be Tyrion (overwhelmingly), Robb, Brienne, and the Red Viper.  Prince Oberyn leads the current fifth-place candidate, Asha Greyjoy, by over a hundred votes, and the margin is widening.

I've never done one of these before, and I must say, I am finding the results fascinating.  So are my friends at Dark Sword.  Interestingly enough, on Dark Sword's other main lines -- the ranges based on the artwork of Larry Elmore and Keith Parkinson -- the hot babes in chainmail bikinis regularly outsell all other miniatures.  No woman in Westeros would be caught dead in a chainmail bikini, of course (well, actually, if a real woman warrior ever wore one of these things, she WOULD be found dead, and very quickly), but we still made sure to include several hot babes in our own list of choices.  

Well, Asha Greyjoy is doing well enough, and will finish just out of the money, looks like... but Shae and Arianne Martell are both bringing up the rear, running behind even Prince Joffrey at this juncture.  Instead my readers want a dwarf, a bisexual Dornishman, and the homeliest woman in the Seven Kingdoms.  Okay.  

So what does that mean?  Are my readers less horny than Elmore and Parkinson fans?  Do they have something against scantily clad women?  Is it my large female readership weighing in against sexist stereotypes in fantasy?  Is it more just a reflection on the specific characters (Asha's strong showing would suggest that)?

Interesting to speculate, anyway...

The characters who don't make the cut this time will have another shot somewhere down the line, have no fear.  So long as you guys keep buying these, Dark Sword will keep making more, and we hope to get to everyone eventually.

My thanks to all of you who voted.  The turnout has been astonishing.

comments.article: I laughed a lot reading this entry :D

I voted for Tyrion Lannister simply because he is one of my favorite characters in all of literature!  As much as I love a hot lady in a chainmail bikini, an excellently-written badass of short stature will still win the day for me.  :)

My husband wants to know whether Tyrion will be a) with or b) without a nose.

I'm sure we'll be buying Tyrion regardless.

comments.upictitle: Miranda, or so they tell me.: RAWR
comments.article: I second this query.
Your devoted readership prefers characters with substance and style rather than your standard bimbo?

Hey I voted to Lady Stark, thank you. ;)

But seriously, it says something about the intelligence of your readers that they appreciate high fantasy that is still somewhat believable. Anyone can write babes in bikinis.

The answer is obvious, don't you think? The very *second* you write one of the Sand Snakes in a chain mail bikini (and publish the book, of course) sales on the miniature will go through the roof.

Say- why not add that into A Dance With Dragons and get it off to the publisher right away?

...?

Yeah, okay. I know. Brilliant works can't be rushed. But it was worth a try, right?

Well, if I had voted (probably won't buy one, so not voting), I would have gone for Tyrion, Brienne, Samwell, and possibly Asha. Why? Because all the others seem like they'd be awfully generic in miniature form. Admittedly, I'm not the kind of person who buys miniatures, so my viewpoint is bound to seem ridiculously uncouth and uneducated to the kind of person who does. But it's a choice between three handsome yet normal-shaped knights/lords, three fairly generic ladies (or two generic ladies and a generic robe-encased female), a generic swordswoman (with or without a chainmail bikini, it makes not a lot of difference), and a fat man, a dwarf, and a spectacularly hideous female warrior? Bear in mind that the characters themselves are in no way generic, I'm just saying the shape of them is, which is what I think of when I think of miniatures. If I had a miniature collection, I imagine that Tyrion, Samwell, and Brienne would stand out, while the others would blend right in.

But again, that's just me, not the perspective the people who matter. But I'd imagine a roughly congruent line of thought might have tipped the balance against the pretty girls.

My thought follows these lines.

I voted on the characters that I felt would make incredibly interesting miniatures.

Okay, and maybe there was a little bias towards some personal favorites, but on the whole, interesting.

The "hot babes in chainmail bikinis" are becoming cliche'.  Another bikini clad warriores would just become lost in the masses, but Brienne, she stands out!  Besides, these traits that help define the character, I'm sure also help make for more intresting looking miniatures.
I voted for Cat and Robb, and the Dornish figs because I think they would be good for gaming with and would actually fit some of the table top characters I know.
Glad to see the Red Viper doing so well.  One of my favorite characters in the entire series :)

we're not less horny, we're just more kinky!

err. i mean, we're just more... sophisticated! yes, that's it.
I'll second this one.  :p

I voted for Tyrion and Oberyn, because 1) Tyrion is an excellent character and would make an interesting--and unusual--figure, and 2) Oberyn, if done well, could be really fun to paint.

I have never really understood the fascination for chainmail or other bikinis, or gauzy dresses, on miniatures. I play Warhammer, and several of the citadel miniatures ranges feature nude or nearly-nude women, and they seem to be pretty popular. But honestly, if I'm feeling the need to peer at the naked ladies, I either talk to my girlfriend about it, or, use this wondrous thing called the internet. (Which is, after all, for porn.) I just can't see how inch-tall plastic or metal models, where even the best ones are far from life-like, are supposed to be so great. The modeling, no matter how skilled, won't match up to illustrations or imagination. And when it comes to painting, forget about it. Armor, shields, cloaks, robes all present many superior opportunities to create interesting artwork. Besides, if one wants to use the models for a wargame, they might as well be plausible.

I imagine if I was 25mm tall, and made of metal, that I'd have a rather different perspective on it.

comments.upictitle: Miranda, or so they tell me.: RAWR
comments.article:
YAY! I voted for all the currently winning characters! And Asha Greyjoy, too, actually.

Now I'd just like to see the Sand Vipers in miniature form. *grin*

Oh, I'm as horny as the next guy, but I dig the characters I voted for mostly for their cool factor.

I dunno, I just never see miniatures as something to fawn over. Frankly, there are certain "art" forms designed for that. /shrug

well don't underestimate us female readers! i'm looking forward to daenerys, in part because your women are strong and not the chainmail bikini kind of idiots that all those guys are so interested in buying. shae...eh...i wouldn't want a miniature of her. she's such a minor character, and she will obviously fill the slutty miniature niche.

It means that readers want figures because of who the characters are--characters they got to know almost exclusively through printed words and the reader's mental eye. The Tyrion figure isn't intersting because he's a dwarf; he's interesting because he's Tyrion.

Whereas fans of visual arts will be drawn to what is visually pleasing. It's all about the look, not the interior life of the person depicted.

The two groups aren't mutually exclusive, either. I'm sure some readers who want the Tyrion figure for who it represents are very happy to also buy a Chick in Chainmail for what she represents.

Personally, it's either the character himself, or the look of the character that makes the most impact in my decision-making process for which figurine to buy. (Or, at least, which figurine to buy first.) I won't be buying these just to sit on a shelf; I plan on using them in D&D campaigns, which means that if they generally look like the character I make up, I can use them.

For example, the Red Viper is one of my favorite characters, but I'd be interested in the look of a Brienne or Asha figurine for a female Fighter or Rogue.
I'm curious... why are you thinking that way?
comments.subject: Asha as Rogue?

comments.upictitle: Madam Lulzy the Great: Deedlit Relaxing
comments.article: Maybe it means your readers actually like GOOD characters... Shae was a dumb slut, Joffrey is an asshole, and Arianne... eh.
I like the evil characters better actually, except for the Starks of course but that because they are noble and adhere to their ancient ideals.
It means.. no more polls.. you won't sell as many.. than if you did the women in chain mail bikinis..
comments.subject: It means.....

comments.article: I've always found that there's very few female minatures that actually look good. When there's a character that's supposed to be the model of perfection in terms of looks, I'm always a bit disappointed when the figure comes out. Now, if the person is already supposed to be ugly--kinda hard to mess that up. And they make for more interesting figures anyway. Perfect people are boring.

Personally? I voted for the characters that I loved to read about best. What they looked like barely even occurred to me as a vote incentive. The Red Viper was one of the book's highlights. I literally bounce up and down when I come to a Tyrion chapter. Brienne... Brienne is complicated. I love her while being profoundly annoyed by her (when she's being overly obsessive), but nonetheless she makes a huge impression. Arianne Martell on the other hand always reminded me of a high school blonde with her own little click and an artificial view of the world. Shae... a little more memorable, but she never really -did- anything that I could admire. Asha was better... outrageous, yes, and she makes some impact... but she always seemed to see herself differently than how other people saw her. 'Wise in her own eyes', if you will.

By the way. If you so happened to offer a figure for Littlefinger... :D Your problem, George, is that we're not seeing the models. It's not 'oh, hot chick'. If that's what we wanted we'd get the generic minis. I look right through them and see the characters. I think the polls reflect that.
Yeah I am as horny as the next guy but I fail to see how that has anything to do with miniatures... no wait.

Is it my large female readership weighing in against sexist stereotypes in fantasy?
Them and your gay readership!

I voted for Tyrion and Brienne - I can't speak for the rest of your readership, but I feel like I can relate more to the "freaks" than the babes in chainmail bikinis. :D Besides, I want to see what sort of mental vision of Tyrion and Brienne these artists have - I know how they look in my head, but I'm curious to see how an artist would portray them.
